unimpeachable.sentence_1: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.
unimpeachable.meaning_1: adjective: free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach

inequity.sentence_1: After decades of racial inequity, the "separate but equal" doctrine was successfully overturned.
inequity.meaning_1: noun: injustice by virtue of not conforming with rules or standards

elegiac.sentence_1: Few can listen to the elegiac opening bars of the Moonlight sonata without feeling the urge to cry.

inviolable.sentence_1: To many the grass at Wimbledon is inviolable and only greater tennis players are able to enjoy a game there.
inviolable.meaning_1: adjective: never to be broken, infringed, or dishonored

impervious.sentence_1: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.
impervious.meaning_1: adjective: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected

pellucid.sentence_1: The professor had a remarkable ability to make even the most difficult concepts seem pellucid.

bridle.sentence_2: The hostess bridled at the tactless dinner guests who insisted on eating before everybody had gotten their food.
bridle.sentence_1: New curfew laws have bridled people's tendency to go out at night.
bridle.meaning_1: verb: the act of restraining power or action or limiting excess
bridle.meaning_2: verb: to react with anger or to take offense

doughty.sentence_1: I enjoy films in which a doughty group comes together to battle a force of evil.

facile.sentence_1: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.
facile.meaning_1: adjective: arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth

turgid.sentence_1: The amount of GRE vocabulary he used increased with his years--by the time he was 60, his novels were so turgid that even his diehard fans refused to read them.

gumption.sentence_1: Wallace Stegner lamented the lack of gumption in the U.S. during the sixties, claiming that no young person knew the value of work.

internecine.sentence_1: The guerilla group, which had become so powerful as to own the state police, was finally destroyed by an internecine conflict.
internecine.meaning_1: adjective: (of conflict) within a group or organization

enormity.sentence_1: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words--within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.
enormity.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
enormity.meaning_1: noun: an act of extreme wickedness

impugn.sentence_1: Though many initially tried to impugn Darwin's theory, in scientific circles today, the idea is taken as truth.
impugn.meaning_1: verb: attack as false or wrong

dolorous.sentence_1: Chopin's ballades are filled with sharp changes in moods--a dolorous melody can give way to a lighthearted tempo.

ethereal.sentence_1: Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.
ethereal.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by lightness and insubstantiality

stultify.sentence_1: As an undergraduate Mark felt stultified by classes outside his area of study; only in grad school, in which he could focus solely on literary analysis, did he regain his scholarly edge.
stultify.meaning_1: verb: cause one, through routine, to lose energy and enthusiasm

hauteur.sentence_1: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice began displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.
hauteur.meaning_1: noun: overbearing pride evidenced by a superior manner toward inferiors

conflate.sentence_1: In her recent book, the author conflates several genres--the detective story, the teen thriller, and the vampire romance--to create a memorable read.
conflate.meaning_1: verb: mix together different elements or concepts

solicitous.sentence_1: Our neighbors are constantly knocking on our door to make sure we are ok, and I don't know how to ask them to stop being so solicitous about our health.
solicitous.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

self-effacing.sentence_1: The most admirable teachers and respected leaders are those who are self-effacing, directing attention and praise to their students and workers.
self-effacing.meaning_1: adjective: reluctant to draw attention to yourself

mendicant.sentence_1: Tolstoy was an aristocrat, but he strove to understand the Christianity of the Russian peasants by wandering among them as a mendicant.
mendicant.meaning_1: noun: a pauper who lives by begging

assiduously.sentence_1: The top college football program recruits new talent assiduously, only choosing those who were the top in their county.

panegyric.sentence_1: Dave asked Andrew to do just a simple toast, but Andrew launched into a full panegyric, enumerating a complete list of Dave's achievements and admirable qualities.
panegyric.meaning_1: noun: a formal expression of praise

complicit.sentence_1: While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.
complicit.meaning_1: adjective: Associated with or participating in an activity, especially one of a questionable nature.

conflagration.sentence_1: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, due to the heat and lack of rain.
conflagration.meaning_1: noun: a very intense and uncontrolled fire

palatable.sentence_1: Mikey didn't partake much in his friends' conversations, but found their presence palatable.
palatable.meaning_1: adjective: acceptable to the taste or mind

malingerer.sentence_1: At one time, our country was full of hardworking respectful people, but now it seems that everyone is a malingerer with little inclination to work.
malingerer.meaning_1: noun: someone shirking their duty by pretending to be sick or incapacitated

desiccated.sentence_1: Few novelists over 80 are able to produce anything more than desiccated works--boring shadows of former books.
desiccated.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

aplomb.sentence_1: Nancy acted with aplomb during dangerous situations--she once calmly climbed up an oak tree to save a cat.
aplomb.meaning_1: noun: great coolness and composure under strain

abjure.sentence_1: While the church believed that Galileo abjured the heliocentric theory under threat of torture, he later wrote a book clearly supporting the theory.
abjure.meaning_1: verb: formally reject or give up (as a belief)

callow.sentence_1: Both Los Angeles and New York are known for callow out-of-towners hoping to make it big.

desideratum.sentence_1: The desideratum of the environmental group is that motorists should rely on carpooling.
desideratum.meaning_1: noun: something desired as a necessity

fecund.sentence_1: The artist had entered a fecund period, producing three masterpieces in the span of two months.

vaunted.sentence_1: For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.
vaunted.meaning_1: adjective: highly or widely praised or boasted about

complaisant.sentence_1: On her first day at the job, Annie was complaisant, fulfilling every request of her new employer and anticipating future requests.
complaisant.meaning_1: adjective: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others

pontificate.sentence_1: The vice-president would often pontificate about economic theory, as if no one else in the room were qualified to speak on the topic.
pontificate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
pontificate.meaning_1: verb: talk in a dogmatic and pompous manner

appropriate.sentence_2: The committe appropriated the funds to its various members.
appropriate.sentence_1: The government appropriated land that was occupied by squatters, sending them scurrying for another place to live.
appropriate.meaning_1: verb: to give or take something by force
appropriate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions, but these are the most important ones to study

proselytize.sentence_1: Lisa loves her Mac but says little about it; by contrast, Jake will proselytize, interrogating anyone with an Android about why she didn't purchase an iPhone.
proselytize.meaning_1: verb: convert (someone) to another religion, philosophy, or perspective

noisome.sentence_1: Each August, when the winds moved in a south easterly direction, the garbage dump would spread noisome vapors through the small town.
noisome.meaning_1: adjective: having an extremely bad smell

autocratic.sentence_2: The manager was finally fired for his autocratic leadership, which often bordered on rude and offensive.
autocratic.sentence_1: The last true autocratic country is certainly North Korea; nowhere does a leader exercise the absolute control over all aspects of a people the way that Kim Jong-un does.
autocratic.meaning_1: adjective: characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule; having absolute sovereignty
autocratic.meaning_2: adjective: offensively self-assured or given to exercising usually unwarranted power

tyro.sentence_1: All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time—unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.
tyro.meaning_1: noun: someone new to a field or activity

discursive.sentence_1: Many readers find it tough to read Moby Dick since the author is discursive, often cutting the action short to spend 20 pages on the history of a whale.
discursive.meaning_1: adjective: (of e.g. speech and writing) tending to depart from the main point

obtuse.sentence_1: Jackson was the most obtuse member of the team: the manager's subtle ironies were always lost on him.
obtuse.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
obtuse.meaning_1: adjective: slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity; lacking in insight or discernment

transmute.sentence_1: One of the goals of alchemy was to find the substance or process that would transmute lead into gold.
transmute.meaning_1: verb: change or alter in form, appearance, or nature

coterminous.sentence_1: The border of the state is coterminous with geographic limits on travel; the east and north are surrounded by a nearly uncrossable river and the south by a desert.
coterminous.meaning_1: adjective: being of equal extent or scope or duration

bromide.sentence_1: Instead of sharing his umbrella, the cheeky stranger offered Martha the following bromide: "Looks like it's raining."
bromide.meaning_1: noun: a trite or obvious remark

unassailable.sentence_1: Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.
unassailable.meaning_1: adjective: immune to attack; without flaws

proscribe.sentence_1: My doctor proscribed my habit of eating donuts with chocolate sauce and hamburger patties for breakfast.

afford.sentence_1: The summit of Mt. Kilimanjaro affords a panoramic view that encompasses both Tanzania and Kenya.
afford.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
